column2: What is the current status of the internet shutdown? Is it ongoing?
column4: Which country did the shutdown occur in?
column5: What is the scope of the shutdown?
column6: Which area(s) city(ies) or region(s) were affected by this shutdown?
column7: What type of shutdown is this?

column11: Who was the decision maker? Please provide any further information you have on who ordered the shutdown.
column12: What was the actual cause of the shutdown?
column13: Please provide further details on the actual cause of the internet shutdown, if known.
column14: What is your primary source for this shutdown?
column15: Please enter the reference links of the source if applicable. If there are more than one, divide them with a ";" mark.
column16: What was the official justification given for the shutdown?
column17: Please give any further details on the official justification of the internet shutdown.
column18: Has the Government acknowledged the shutdown?
column19: Did the government or relevant authority give any legal justification or refer to a law?
column20: Did the government or relevant authority use a memo, court order or similar instrument? Please provide a brief summary.
column21: Please include a link to the official statement relating to the shutdown, if available.
column22: Please include a quote from the relevant authorities relating to the justification of the shutdown, if available.
column28: Please list any other web-based services that were specifically targeted during the service-based shutdown.
column29: Were SMS services specifically targeted during the shutdown?
column30: Were calling services specifically targeted during the shutdown?
column31: Which Telco was involved in the shutting down of the internet or services?

column34: Please provide a quote from the Telco if they have acknowledged the shutdown, if possible.
column35: Did this shutdown involve an election?
column36: Did this shutdown involve physical violence?
column37: Have any human rights abuses been reported that specifically relate to this shutdown?

column39: Please provide any further details on the users targeted in the shutdown.
column40: Did users affected by the shutdown receive advance warning?
column41: Please provide a short one- or two-sentence summary of the shutdown and the event that triggered it. Please note: This may be displayed publicly by Access Now.
column42: Please provide a reference link to an article about the shutdown on Access Now's homepage, if applicable.
column43: Please include any notes about this shutdown you feel are relevant for the KIO team. They will not be shared with external partners.

column16: Fake news/ Hate speech/ Incendiary content/ Promoting violence
column17: Acts of terrorism, act of disturbance, and illegal activities
column41: Predominantly Rohingya, residents in Myanmarâ€™s Chin and Rakhine states have been suffering through lengthy internet shutdowns and slowdowns since June 2019. As another obstacle to internet access for minority communities, authorities in Myanmar deactivated more than 34 million SIM cards this year, after people failed to reregister them with National Registration Card (NRC) numbers.

column5: It affected more than one city in the same state, province, or region
column20: Yes. During 2021 the government issued Orders 01(TSTS) OF 2021, 02(TSTS) OF 2021, and 07(TSTS) of 2021, which referred to this incident. In 2021, mobile internet was still throttled until 05 of February, in most districts of Jammu and Kashmir.
column41: During 2021 the government issued Orders 01(TSTS) OF 2021, 02(TSTS) OF 2021, and 07(TSTS) of 2021, which referred to the ongoing mobile internet throttling. It ended by 05 of February. Before then, most districts of Jammu and Kashmir only had 2g mobile internet during 2021. In previous years and continuous to this event, there were full broadband and mobile shutdowns.

column5: It affected locations in more than one state, province, or region
column13: Civil war in Tigray region
column17: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uEoa-7J6zpY
column41: Full shutdown is ongoing in the Tigray region during a civil war. This happened at the start of the conflict and the government blamed the Tigray military forces for destruction of infrastructure. Nevertheless, after promises of restoration of services by the National Government, the internet services remain inaccessible in Tigray, amid various reports of human rights abuses.

column16: Public safety/ Quell unrest / Restore public order
column17: "In the interest of maintaining public safety and averting public emergency, it is necessary and expedient to order the temporary suspension of the internet services in the areas of Singhu, Ghazipur, Tikri, Mukarba Chowk and Nangloi and their adjoining areas in the NCT of Delhi from 1200 hours to 23:59 hours on jan 26, 2021."
column41: Government-mandated internet shutdowns in response to the #FarmersProtest. Mobile internet and SMS has been targeted in an attempt to block protester communication. The Internet has not been fully restored in most areas that were initially cut off on January 26, and the shutdowns have reportedly been extended in some areas until February 6.

column41: There was a full shutdown among some telecommunication companies at the Gaza strip,  after Israeli Airforce bombings in the region (electrictiy outage as well). One of the the internet outages started at the same time as the bombing of the Al-Jalaa tower, where Associated Press and Al Jazeera operated, as well as Telecoms (May 15). The bombing of the Al-Jawahra tower also affected telecom operators with infrastructure in the building (May 12).
